+    r"""Returns the matrix norm or vector norm of a given tensor.

+            None   Frobenius norm                2-norm

+            'nuc'  nuclear norm                  --
+            inf    max(sum(abs(x), dim=1))       max(abs(x))
+            -inf   min(sum(abs(x), dim=1))       min(abs(x))
+            0      --                            sum(x != 0)
+            1      max(sum(abs(x), dim=0))       as below
+            -1     min(sum(abs(x), dim=0))       as below
+            2      largest singular value        as below
+            -2     smallest singular value       as below
+            other  as vec norm when dim is None  sum(abs(x)**ord)**(1./ord)
+            =====  ============================  ==========================
+        dim ({int, 2-tuple of ints, 2-list of ints}): If it is a int, vector norm

body: On production, we have a function "torch.norm(input, p=2) → Tensor". Therefore, there are numerous places in the codebase where it called .norm() directly. "fro" is the default value for attr:p now as Numpy did and "fro" is equal 2-norm when calling vector norm as I mentioned in the intro. With this condition check, .norm() will have the same behavior as before.
